p.s: Starr is presented as a fragile and shy person at first but goes on to be very confident towards the end.
In the beginning Starr is very anxious because shesshe's in the place Khalil got killed and sees it go down in front of her again.
Then she speaks with Ms. Ofrah, her attorney, who speaks with her and gives her the courage to speak up.
She is still a little shy at first but after a police officer says that they all should leave the street immediately, she snaps and speaks up.
That points out the anger she buildbuilt up in her since the murder of Khalil happened.
The whole passage is written from StarrsStarr's perspective, that is supposed to let us empathize better with Starr.
In the given text direct speech and Starr's inner thoughts are relatively even and we can see good what goes through Starr's mind and what the other people are saying.
The crowd of people is presented very understanding and encouraging while the police officer is not understanding.
That is because itsit's Starr's perspective and she is very emotional at that moment.
The crowd is often depicted as one beeingbeing because it's only referred to as the crowd not the people in the crowd.
That is done to help the reader follow the story better if it would have been depicted as multiple people it could have been very chaotic reading the passage.
Through that depiction as some sort of hive mind / one beeingbeing there are only four major people.
inIn the given text, Starr; Ms. Ofrah; the police officer / and the crowd by major I mean that they have ana good effect on what happens there.
